channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Way of the World: Some Cracks in the Cult of Technocrats
item.description: In the wake of a global crisis that technocrats both helped cause and failed to predict, there are sound reasons not to rely on technocratic solutions.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: British Security Chiefs Meet After Killing
item.description: One day after a soldier was hacked to death in broad daylight on a London street, Prime Minister David Cameron said Britain would be “absolutely resolute” in confronting militants.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron, center, and Mayor Boris Johnson of London spoke to Woolwich residents on Thursday.

item.title: In Mideast, Kerry Plays Down Pessimism on Peace
item.description: On his fourth visit to the area in two months, Secretary of State John Kerry acknowledged the doubts being expressed on both sides over his chances of revitalizing the peace process.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Future of High-Tech Immigrants to the U.S.
item.description: Foreign graduate students at U.C. Berkeley reflect on how immigration reform could make it easier for highly skilled workers to stay in the United States. Or encourage them to return home.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: The Caucus: Q & A: Answering Readers’ Queries on Drones
item.description: The Times’s national security reporting team responded to readers’ questions about drones ahead of President Obama’s speech on counterterrorism policy on Thursday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Envoy Says North Korea Open to Dialogue
item.description: The North Korean envoy, Marshal Choe Ryong-hae, said the North would “accept the proposal” by China, its biggest benefactor which it has strained relations with.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Afghan Students Protest Women’s Rights Decree
item.description: Hard-line Islamist students protested in Kabul demanding the repeal of a presidential decree for women’s rights that they say is un-Islamic.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Questions in London Killing Echo Boston Bombing
item.description: After the brutal daylight murder of an off-duty soldier in a London suburb, questions about homegrown threats and copy cats resonate in the British capital, as calm prevails.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Women laid flowers on Thursday at the scene of the London murder.

item.title: IHT Special: Dubai Hotels Struggle to Fill Jobs
item.description: Employers are finding it difficult to find staff from entry level to senior management who have all the necessary skills.
item.dc:creator: By SARA HAMDAN

item.title: India Ink: What the Congress-Led Government Thinks It Got Right
item.description: The United Progressive Alliance touted an average 8 percent annual growth rate as one of its major achievements in eight of the nine years it has been in power.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh with Sonia Gandhi, chairperson of United Progressive Alliance, in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Job Hunting in Asia: Language Skills Count
item.description: Westerners seeking work in places like Hong Kong and Singapore are finding that language skills — good Mandarin, in particular — have become more essential.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: A worker cleans a signboard in Beijing.

item.title: India Ink: Collapse of Ponzi Scheme Spreads Panic in West Bengal
item.description: An estimated $5.5 billion have been lost and over 3 million people have been affected in one of the biggest financial frauds in India.
item.dc:creator: By SHANTANU GUHA RAY
item.media:description: A woman with her investment certificate for Saradha Group in Baruipur, West Bengal, on May 9.

item.title: Malaysian Opposition Figures Are Detained
item.description: The arrests came two and a half weeks after elections that showed the governing party losing support with broad portions of the multicultural electorate.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 23
item.description: Hezbollah and Europe; Fears of terrorism in Britain; Society’s ills in Greece; North Korean envoy in China; the end of European tax havens; tackling youth unemployment; art fair in Hong Kong; Gibraltar’s soccer bid.
item.dc:creator: By INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: 13 Pakistani Police Officers Killed in Explosion
item.description: The province where the attacks took place, Baluchistan, has been the site of a separatist insurgency and violence by other militants.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Security personnel examined a police vehicle on Thursday after it was struck by a roadside bomb in Quetta, Pakistan.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Increases of Cash Handouts to Poor
item.description: Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, has announced increases of as much as 35 percent in cash handouts to the poor, students, pregnant women and retirees.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Financial Watchdog’s Report Is Released
item.description: The Vatican, in addition to publishing the first report from its financial watchdog agency, announced new regulations to fight money laundering and terrorism financing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Riots Continue in Immigrant Neighborhoods
item.description: Hundreds of young people burned cars and attacked police officers this week in three nights of riots in immigrant neighborhoods of Stockholm, Sweden’s capital.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Iceland: Leader of Center-Right Is New Prime Minister
item.description: Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson was chosen as Iceland’s new prime minister and promptly announced a halt to talks with the European Union about joining the 27-nation bloc.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Man Held in 1982 Attack on Queen’s Cavalry
item.description: British prosecutors have charged a 61-year-old Irishman, John Downey, with the 1982 I.R.A. attack on the queen’s cavalry in Hyde Park that left four soldiers and seven horses dead.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Active Fault May Block Restart of Tsuruga Reactor in Japan
item.description: The No. 2 reactor at Tsuruga now faces indefinite stoppage or likely decommissioning unless its operator provides new data on the fault.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Israel Is Drawn Into Syria’s Turmoil
item.description: Israelis are asking what their options are, as if they feel it has become impossible to avoid deeper involvement in Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier at a training ground in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, near the increasingly volatile border with Syria.

item.title: Kerry May Make Bid to Restart Mideast Peace Talks
item.description: Since becoming secretary of state, John Kerry has worked to jump-start the stalled peace process, embracing a seemingly intractable issue.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: U.S. Fears Syria Fighting Might Spill Into Lebanon
item.description: The decision by Hezbollah to fight for the Syrian government, and the prospect that Syrian rebels might fight Hezbollah operatives in Lebanon, has alarmed the Obama administration.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with King Abdullah II of Jordan in Amman on Wednesday. Mr. Kerry said Lebanon was “at risk” of being swept up in the Syrian civil war.

item.title: Long Wait for a Green Card Could Be Ending
item.description: Born overseas and educated in the United States, workers in the heart of the tech industry are in a kind of suspension as the Senate considers the immigration bill.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Kartik Shah, 29, has been waiting six years for a green card.
